questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with the lesion shown below in the x-ray. Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GCT

 

GIANT CELL TUMOUR (GCT)

 

  • They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance.
  • The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.
  • Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group.
  • Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Difference between Aneurysmal bone cyst and GCT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst. A dermoid cyst is a benign cutaneous developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure. These benign tumors are lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mature skin appendages found on their wall and their lumens filled with keratin and hair. Dermoid cysts are considered to be congenital, but not all of them are diagnosed at birth. Only about 40% of dermoid cysts are diagnosed at birth, while about 60% are diagnosed by five years of age. The dermoid cysts usually present within the first year of life and grow slowly. Dermoid cysts occur most commonly on the head and neck. The etiology of dermoid cysts remains mostly unknown. These occur when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development. In the head and neck region, dermoid cysts can most commonly be seen in the frontal, occipital, and supraorbital areas, with the outer third of the eyebrow being the most frequently affected region.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumor of distal end radius is always GCT until proven otherwise.
  • Mc site of giant cell tumor is lower end femur.
  • Lower end femur is Mc site for:
    • Giant cell tumor
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Osteomyelitis

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. The patient is conscious, alert, and hemodynamically stable. Upon examination, the patient reports that the pain began suddenly. A chest X-ray is performed, which reveals some abnormal findings. Identify the condition shown below and its management?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • Given the clinical picture of acute-onset severe abdominal pain and a chest X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm, the diagnosis of hollow viscus perforation is suspected, and the appropriate management is an emergency laparotomy.
  • A hollow viscus perforation leads to the spillage of enteric contents into the abdominal cavity. This can cause acute peritonitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the peritoneal cavity.
  • Emergency laparotomy is the surgical opening of the abdomen to investigate and treat the cause of the acute abdominal pain. It can confirm the diagnosis, identify the source of the perforation, and treat it, often by repairing or resecting the affected section of the bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric lavage:

 

  • Gastric lavage, often referred to as "stomach pumping," is a procedure that involves the insertion of a tube into the stomach to remove its contents. It's often used in cases of drug overdose or ingestion of toxic substances.
  • In the context of sudden abdominal pain and air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, this option is not appropriate since the problem is not related to the contents of the stomach but rather a perforation.

 

Option C. Ultrasound:

 

  • While it can be used in the evaluation of various abdominal conditions, in the context of acute severe pain and a suggestive chest X-ray, ultrasound wouldn't be the primary diagnostic modality.
  • Air (as from a perforated viscus) is a poor conductor of ultrasound waves, which makes ultrasound less reliable in this setting compared to other imaging modalities.

 

Option D. Chest tube insertion:

 

  • A chest tube is inserted between the ribs to drain air, blood, or fluid from the pleural space. This is usually done in conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion.
  • While the X-ray may show air under the diaphragm, this air is in the abdomen and not in the pleural space of the chest.
  • Given the acute presentation and the imaging findings, the correct management is emergency laparotomy to address the underlying perforation and prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.
  • Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following rapid ascent to over 3000 metres above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in treatment of the above condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IV digoxin

 

The condition described in the scenario is likely High-Altitude Headache (HAH) and High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE), which can occur due to rapid ascent to high altitudes.

 

Digoxin is a medication primarily used for the treatment of heart conditions, such as heart failure and certain irregular heart rhythms like atrial fibrillation therefore, digoxin is not used for the above condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediate Descent: This is the most effective treatment for HAPE and other altitude sickness symptoms. Descending to lower altitudes where the air pressure is higher can alleviate symptoms by increasing the available oxygen.

 

Option C. Administration of Oxygen: Providing supplemental oxygen can help alleviate the symptoms of hypoxia experienced at high altitudes, directly addressing the oxygen deficit caused by the thin air.

 

Option D. Tablet Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a diuretic that helps prevent and reduce the symptoms of altitude sickness. It works by acidifying the blood, which stimulates breathing, increasing oxygen intake and helping the body adjust to changes in altitude.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barometric pressure, partial pressure of oxygen and common effects at different altitudes

 

 

Treatment

 

  1. Oxygen supplementation
  2. Move to a lower altitude
  3. Acetazolamide – stimulates respiration and reduced intracranial pressure
  4. Portable hyperbaric bags (E.g., Gamow bag) simulate descent to a lower altitude.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. DC shock

 

The patient presents with symptoms of palpitations and dizziness and is found to have an irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG, consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). The absence of distinct P waves and the presence of fibrillatory waves further support this diagnosis.

 

The patient's vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 84/46 mm Hg, indicating hemodynamic instability. In cases of tachyarrhythmias such as AF, the management approach depends on the patient's hemodynamic status. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable, immediate intervention is required.

 

Synchronized DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients with AF. This procedure involves delivering a synchronized shock to restore normal rhythm. The shock is timed (synchronized) to occur at the peak of the R wave to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation.

 

Specific contraindications for using synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion (synchronized DC shocking) are sinus tachycardia, multifocal atrial tachycardia digoxin toxicity. But in cases where a patient is unstable and experiencing shock, immediate cardioversion is necessary despite these contraindications, underscoring the urgency in treating life-threatening arrhythmias in acute settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent thromboembolic events in patients with AF. However, it is not the immediate intervention of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients. The priority in such cases is to stabilize the patient's condition, which requires electrical cardioversion.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used to control the heart rate in AF. They are not appropriate for initial management in an unstable patient, as they do not address the immediate need to restore a stable rhythm.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used in the management of AF. However, it is typically used in stable patients or after electrical cardioversion has been attempted. In an unstable patient, immediate electrical cardioversion is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the next step to restore a stable rhythm and improve hemodynamic status.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the CT image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PUJO (Pelviureteric Junction Obstruction)

 

The CT image shows a massively dilated renal pelvis with thinning of the renal parenchyma, which is characteristic of Pelviureteric Junction Obstruction (PUJO). In PUJO, the obstruction occurs at the junction between the renal pelvis and the ureter, causing the pelvis to become disproportionately dilated compared to the calyces. This results in significant thinning of the renal tissue, which is evident in the image. The appearance of a stretched and thin parenchyma alongside a dilated pelvis points towards PUJO.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Renal cyst: A renal cyst typically appears as a single, fluid-filled, well-defined lesion within the kidney. The key feature is that it would appear as a solitary or few non-communicating cysts, unlike the diffuse dilation and thin parenchyma seen in PUJO.

 

Option C.  AD PCKD (Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease): AD PCKD is characterized by multiple cysts throughout the kidney, which are typically non-communicating and cause the kidneys to become enlarged and lobulated. In contrast, the CT here shows a single, large, dilated pelvis rather than multiple distinct cysts.

 

Option D.  Horseshoe kidney: A horseshoe kidney is a congenital condition where the kidneys are fused at the lower poles, forming a horseshoe shape. It does not present with significant pelvis dilation or obstructive features as seen in this CT image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PUJO is characterized by massive dilation of the renal pelvis with thinning of the renal parenchyma due to obstruction at the pelviureteric junction. The pelvis is more dilated than the calyces, which is a hallmark finding on imaging.

choices.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury and his serum K+ level was found to be 5.5 mEq/L. What change will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Becomes more positive

 

Explanation

 

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can cause a shift in the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value, increased cell excitability, and impairments in membrane potential changes.

 

Hyperkalemia can affect the resting membrane potential of cells, including neurons and muscle cells, in the following ways:

 

  1. Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value.
  2. Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli.
  3. Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials.
  4.  Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No change: Incorrect. Changes in extracellular potassium concentrations directly impact the resting membrane potential.

 

Option B. Becomes more negative: Incorrect. An increase in extracellular potassium concentration results in depolarization (more positive resting membrane potential), not hyperpolarization.

 

Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative: Incorrect. While complex fluctuations can occur under dynamic conditions, primarily, hyperkalemia causes a persistent depolarization (more positive shift) without an initial opposite change.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hyperkalemia, as seen in patients with severe muscle injury, the resting membrane potential becomes more positive due to decreased potassium efflux, leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells. This can affect the normal function of these cells, potentially leading to complications such as muscle weakness or cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: What type of budding is described by a broad base with a small bud coming off of it, often associated with a figure of 8 appearances? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blastomycosis

 

The term "broad based budding" refers to a type of asexual reproduction in fungi where the bud forms from a broad base rather than a narrow one. This specific budding pattern is characteristic of Blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by the organism Blastomyces dermatitidis. The appearance of the yeast cells in Blastomycosis is often described as having a broad base with a budding structure that resembles a figure of 8. This visual characteristic is useful in distinguishing Blastomycosis from other fungal infections. The mnemonic "Blasto" helps to remember that "Blasto" implies broad-based budding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: This fungus is known for producing yeast cells with a round, encapsulated appearance and does not exhibit broad-based budding. Instead, it forms a distinctive capsule around the yeast cells which is crucial for its identification.

 

Option C. Candidiasis: The causative agent, Candida species, typically shows pseudohyphae and yeast forms, but these do not have the broad-based budding pattern. Candida's budding is more narrow-based compared to that of Blastomycosis.

 

Option D.Histoplasmosis: Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, this fungus forms small yeast cells within macrophages. The budding in Histoplasmosis is more narrow-based and does not resemble the broad-based budding pattern described for Blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blastomycosis is characterized by broad-based budding with a figure of 8 appearances, where the term "Blasto" helps recall the broad base nature of the budding structure.

questions.text:
Which are the tumor markers for the ultrasound image shown below? (NEET PG 2024)

 

 

 

  1. CA 125
  2. LDH
  3. AFP
  4. hCG
  5. CA 19-9
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1,2,3,4,5


The ultrasound image shows an ovarian mass, and various tumor markers are used in the evaluation of ovarian tumors to help in diagnosis and management:

 

  1. CA 125: This is primarily used as a marker for epithelial ovarian cancer, especially serous cystadenocarcinoma. Elevated levels of CA 125 are often associated with advanced stages of the disease.
  2. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): This marker is associated with dysgerminoma, a type of germ cell tumor of the ovary. Elevated LDH levels can suggest the presence of this tumor.
  3. AFP (Alpha-Fetoprotein): AFP is a marker used for yolk sac tumors, which are rare but aggressive ovarian germ cell tumors.
  4. hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): hCG is elevated in cases of non-gestational choriocarcinoma, which is another form of germ cell tumor.
  5. CA 19-9: This tumor marker is associated with mucinous cystadenocarcinoma, a type of ovarian epithelial tumor. It is also elevated in other gastrointestinal malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Different tumor markers, including CA 125, LDH, AFP, hCG, and CA 19-9, are utilized to assess ovarian masses and differentiate between various types of ovarian tumors.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)

 

  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche - absent
  • FSH, LH - high
  • Karyotype - 46 XX
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gonadal dysgenesis

 

Explanation:

 

The probable diagnosis in this case is pure gonadal dysgenesis. Primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics (thelarche) and high levels of FSH and LH indicate hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, which suggests an ovarian cause. The karyotype 46 XX confirms gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Testicular feminizing syndrome/Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome

 

  • This condition occurs in individuals with a 46 XY karyotype.
  • Individuals with this syndrome have absent uterus and ovaries and exhibit secondary sexual development, especially breast development, due to peripheral production of estrogens.

 

Option C. Kallmann Syndrome

 

  • This is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leading to primary amenorrhea.
  • It is associated with anosmia and absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • FSH and LH levels are low in this condition.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome

 

  • Characterized by a 45 XO karyotype.
  • Individuals have streak ovaries leading to low estrogen levels and absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • FSH and LH levels are high.
  • A very important feature is short stature, which is not seen in the patient described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with high FSH and LH levels and a 46 XX karyotype indicates gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Ref: Page no 454, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

 

The most likely organism based on the given history and image is Trichophyton rubrum. The colonies appear velvety and a deep red, non-diffusible pigment is seen when viewed from the reverse side of the colony. A few long and pencil-shaped macroconidia can be seen.

 

Trichophyton is a dermatophytic fungi that can infect hair, skin, or nails. Dermatophytes infect only the keratinized tissue and have keratinases that can digest keratin. There are 3 genera of dermatophytes:

 

  • ﻿﻿Trichophyton - The colonies may appear powdery, waxy, or velvety with pigmentation characteristics of different species.
  • ﻿﻿Epidermophyton - It infects the skin and nails, but not the hair. The colonies appear powdery and greenish-yellow.
  • Microsporum - It infects the hair and skin, but not the nails. The colonies may appear cotton-like, velvety, or powdery, with white to brown pigmentation.

 

Trichophyton rubrum causes tinea corporis. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum, with lesions on the trunk and limbs. The lesions are usually well-defined and circular with a raised edge. It can also cause tinea pedis, tinea cruris, and onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The colonies of Trichophyton violaceus are very slow-growing, waxy with a violet/purple pigment. They have distorted hyphae, with conidia seen rarely.

 

 

Option C. Trichophyton tonsurans has a cream or yellowish colony with central furrows. Microconidia are abundantly seen. Thick-walled, irregular macroconidia are also seen.

 

 

Option D. Colonies of Trichophyton schoenleinii are smooth, waxy and brownish. Hyphal swellings are seen along with chlamydospores and favic chandelier.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male came to the emergency after sustaining an injury and was given 0.25% bupivacaine for regional anesthesia. A few minutes later, he became unresponsive and pulseless. What would be the ideal management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CPR & 20% IV Intralipid

 

The scenario describes a case of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur after the administration of local anesthetics like bupivacaine. LAST can cause severe cardiovascular and central nervous system toxicity, leading to symptoms such as seizures, coma, and cardiovascular collapse, as seen in this patient.

 

The management of LAST involves:

 

  1. Immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) if the patient is unresponsive and pulseless.
  2. Administration of 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid). This treatment, known as lipid rescue or lipid emulsion therapy, acts by creating a "lipid sink" that absorbs the local anesthetic from the tissues and blood, reducing its toxic effects on the heart and brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPR & Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is not the primary treatment for local anesthetic toxicity. It is used in cases of hyperkalemia or calcium channel blocker overdose.

 

Option C. CPR & Start Dobutamine infusion: While dobutamine can support cardiac function, it is not specific for treating local anesthetic toxicity and does not address the underlying cause.

 

Option D. CPR & Start NaHCO3 infusion: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat metabolic acidosis and certain poisonings, such as tricyclic antidepressant overdose, but it is not specific for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), immediate management includes starting CPR and administering 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid) therapy. This approach helps to rapidly reduce the toxic effects of the local anesthetic on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

questions.text:
To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, what level should the rate of couple protection exceed? [NEET PG 2018]

 

(NRR: Net reproduction rate)
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 60% 

 

The Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) is a measure of the average number of daughters a woman would have if she passed through her lifetime conforming to the age-specific fertility and mortality rates of a given year. An NRR of 1 means that each woman is, on average, having one daughter who survives to reproductive age, thereby replacing herself without population growth or decline.

 

To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) must exceed 60%. This aligns with the scenario where every couple has two children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, the rate of couple protection should exceed 60%. This level of contraceptive use helps in maintaining a stable population by ensuring that each woman, on average, has one daughter who survives to reproductive age.

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T cell

 

Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell.

 

A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species.

 

Nude mice lack body hair, hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The absence of functioning T cells also prevents the rejection of allografts & xenografts.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. B cell: Incorrect because the primary immunodeficiency in nude mice relates to T cells, not B cells. While B cells are essential for antibody production, their presence does not compensate for the lack of T cell-mediated immunity necessary for xenograft rejection.

 

Option C. Both B and T cell: Incorrect as nude mice specifically lack T cells due to the absence of a thymus, while B cell function remains intact.

 

Option D. INK cell: Incorrect because the term should likely refer to "NK cells" (natural killer cells), which are not the primary reason for the lack of xenograft rejection in nude mice. NK cells can participate in innate immune responses but do not compensate for the lack of adaptive immune responses mediated by T cells in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


Nude mice lack a thymus, resulting in a deficiency of mature T cells, which are essential for rejecting xenografts. This highlights the crucial role of T cells in adaptive immune responses and graft rejection.

questions.text: The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hormone receptor staining

 

Hormone receptor status, which determines if the tumor cells have receptors for hormones like estrogen and progesterone, is not included in the VNPI. While hormone receptor status is crucial for managing invasive breast cancers, as it determines potential responses to hormone therapies like tamoxifen, it's not a component of the Van Nuys grading system for DCIS.

 

Staining for estrogen and progesterone receptors is not part of the Van Nuys system used for grading DCIS.

 

The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a grading system that helps to stratify patients with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) based on several factors to determine the likelihood of recurrence and guide treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age of the patient: The age of the patient is one of the factors in the Van Nuys Prognostic Index. Younger age (below 40) is associated with a higher risk of recurrence.

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Tumor size is an essential factor in the Van Nuys grading system. Larger DCIS lesions (> 4cm) are associated with a higher risk of recurrence. Thus, the size can influence the treatment approach.

 

Option D. Presence of necrosis: In DCIS, the presence or absence of necrosis plays a role in determining the prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include Hormone receptor staining.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old female from a tribal area who presents with fever for the last 3 days, which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her illness based on the diagnosis of malaria made through examination of the peripheral smear? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P. falciparum

 

The image shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of P. falciparum.

 

There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P. malariae: Causes quartan malaria with a longer incubation period and typically presents with band-form trophozoites across the red cells, distinct from the forms seen in P. falciparum.

 

Option C. P. ovale: Known for causing tertian malaria with similar clinical presentations to P. vivax, including the presence of Schüffner's dots and slightly enlarged and ovale-shaped erythrocytes.

 

Option D. P. vivax: Also causes tertian malaria, characterized by Schüffner's stippling in erythrocytes, larger ring forms than P. falciparum, and less severe disease outcomes compared to P. falciparum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identification of P. falciparum through the presence of distinctive ring forms in red blood cells on a peripheral smear is crucial for rapid initiation of appropriate antimalarial therapy, particularly in endemic regions. Early treatment is vital to prevent severe complications and reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: Which one of the provided thermometers is employed for measuring low air velocity as opposed to the cooling potency of the air? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Kata thermometer 

 

Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity rather than the cooling power of the air. It works by measuring the temperature difference between two thin wires heated to different temperatures in a moving air stream. The faster the air moves, the greater the temperature difference between the two wires, allowing the Kata thermometer to measure air velocity.

 

Other Options

Option B. Globe Thermometer: Measures mean radiant temperature, which is the average temperature of all the surfaces surrounding a particular point. This is useful in assessing thermal comfort in environments.

 

Option C. Wet Globe Thermometer: Used to measure heat stress by taking into account temperature, humidity, wind speed, and solar radiation. It is commonly used in the Wet Bulb Globe Temperature (WBGT) index.

Option D. Dial Thermometer: Measures air temperature using a dial indicator. It is a general-purpose thermometer and not specifically designed for measuring air velocity.


Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness? NEET PG 2022
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of post-operative hypocalcemia, likely due to ischemia of all 4 parathyroid glands or their accidental removal.
  • To assess the possibility of hypoparathyroidism following thyroidectomy, the patient's levels of calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) should be evaluated.
  • The patient's symptoms of perioral numbness after a total thyroidectomy raise suspicion for hypocalcemia due to potential damage to or inadvertent removal of the parathyroid glands during surgery or due to their ischemia.
  •  This option is the most appropriate for the patient's presentation. The parathyroid glands regulate calcium levels in the blood, and their ischemic damage or removal can result in hypocalcemia.
  •  By measuring calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels, one can assess the function of the parathyroid glands and determine if hypocalcemia is the cause of the patient's symptoms. If these levels are abnormal, it would confirm a diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism, which can manifest as symptoms like perioral numbness.
  • Symptoms of hypocalcemia may include circumoral paresthesia, paresthesia of the neck, fingers, and toes, muscle twitching, and weakness of the forearm, hand, and foot, as well as carpopedal spasms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Serum Na, K, and Chloride: Deranged Na/K/Cl are unusual in the setting of thyroidectomy and do not corroborate with the patient’s clinical findings.

 

Option B. T3, T4, Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): These tests are used to evaluate overall thyroid function. These are not the primary tests to evaluate for post-operative hypocalcemia.

 

Option C. Radioiodine scan: This test uses a small amount of radioactive iodine to evaluate the structure and function of the thyroid gland. It's primarily used in the diagnosis and treatment of thyroid diseases like hyperthyroidism or to detect residual thyroid tissue after thyroidectomy in cases of thyroid cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
  • It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used for assessing non-organic hearing loss? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fowler Test

 

Explanation:

 

Fowler Test (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance Test) is not used for diagnosing non-organic hearing loss. It is specifically designed to detect and measure recruitment in unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. In this test, tones of the same frequency but different intensities are presented alternately to both ears, and the patient is asked to compare loudness. The test helps identify cochlear pathology by demonstrating recruitment phenomenon, where sounds that are barely audible reach uncomfortable loudness with small increases in intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stenger's Test: This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss, particularly unilateral feigned hearing loss. It employs the principle that when tones of different intensities are presented simultaneously to both ears, only the louder tone is perceived. If a patient with claimed unilateral deafness denies hearing a tone presented to both ears (with the "deaf" ear receiving a stronger stimulus), malingering is confirmed.

 

Option C. Lombard's Test: This is correctly used to detect non-organic hearing loss. It relies on the principle that people unconsciously raise their voice when they cannot hear themselves speak. In this test, the patient is asked to read aloud while noise is introduced to their ears. A genuine hearing-impaired person will raise their voice, while a malingerer maintaining normal voice level reveals non-organic hearing loss.

 

Option D. Erhardt's Test: This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss. It employs tuning forks that appear identical but vibrate at different frequencies. The patient is shown which fork corresponds to which tone but cannot actually see which fork is being used in testing. Inconsistent responses reveal the non-organic nature of the hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Fowler Test (ABLB) is designed specifically to detect recruitment in sensorineural hearing loss, particularly of cochlear origin, and is not part of the standard test battery for identifying non-organic hearing loss or malingering.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is the next line of management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colposcopy directed biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

A positive pap smear indicates the presence of some cytological abnormality (such as epithelial or glandular cell abnormalities). The next appropriate step is to perform a colposcopy and directed biopsy. Colposcopy provides a magnified view of the cervix, allowing for the identification and biopsy of abnormal areas. During the colposcopy, scoring systems like Ried’s index or Swede’s score are used to evaluate the severity of the pathology, and cervical biopsy samples are taken from acetowhite areas identified during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cone biopsy (Conization):

 

  • Conization is typically reserved for situations where there is:
    • Unsatisfactory colposcopic findings (where the entire lesion cannot be visualized).
    • Inconsistent findings between colposcopy, cytology, and directed biopsy.
    • Positive endocervical curettage.
    • When biopsy cannot rule out invasive cancer from carcinoma in situ (CIS) or microinvasion.

 

Option C. Repeat pap smear:

 

  • This is not preferred in this scenario as the exact abnormality on the pap smear is not specified. In cases of low-grade squamous intra-epithelial lesion (LSIL) with negative HPV, a repeat pap smear with HPV testing may be advised, but this is not applicable here.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy:

 

  • Hysterectomy is never indicated solely for an abnormal pap smear. It is considered only if the colposcopic-directed biopsy shows:
    • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) associated with other gynecologic problems such as prolapse, fibroids, pelvic inflammatory disease, or endometriosis.
    • Persistent dyskaryotic smear despite treatment.
    • High-grade CIN in elderly women.
    • Patients with poor compliance for follow-up.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following a positive pap smear indicating abnormal cytology, the next step is to perform a colposcopy and directed biopsy to further evaluate and manage the cervical pathology.

 

Ref: Page no 329, Dc Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

 

Explanation:

 

  • Misoprostol and Mifepristone:
    • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
    • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
    • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
    • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.

 

Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks of gestation, the recommended drugs are mifepristone followed by misoprostol.

 

 

Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules

questions.text: Where sharp waste can be disposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) White container

 

Sharp waste, which includes items like needles, scalpels, and other sharp objects that can puncture or cut, must be disposed of in containers specifically designed to prevent punctures and leaks. These containers are typically white, puncture-resistant, leak-proof, and tamper-proof. This ensures that sharp objects are safely contained to prevent injuries and the spread of infections.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A young girl has been experiencing repeated instances of yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was only 3 months old. Given her immune system's condition, which of the listed vaccines should not be administered to her? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Measles/MMR

 

Based on the information provided, the girl child has a history of recurrent yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was 3 months old. This suggests that she may have an underlying immunodeficiency.

 

In this scenario, the measles/MMR vaccine would be contraindicated due to the risk of causing a severe infection in an immunocompromised individual.

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF LIVE VACCINES –

 

  • Immunodeficient individuals (Symptomatic HIV infection) except BCG vaccine
  • Immunosuppressed individuals (patient with leukemia or patients on antimetabolites, steroids or radiation)
  • Pregnancy (except Yellow fever)

 

Additional Information

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killed IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it does not contain live virus.

 

Option C. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Option D. TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus and Diphtheria): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live vaccines like Measles/MMR should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals due to the risk of severe infection. Instead, inactivated or subunit vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens, should be used.

choices.text: The extent does not cross the wound margins
Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.text: A patient visits the clinic and presents with a raised and firm scar on their chest, which is larger than the original wound. The physician suspects a keloid scar and begins to explain the diagnosis and potential treatment options. Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

 

A keloid scar forms due to an increase in the level of growth factors: This statement is true. Keloid scars are thought to develop due to an overproduction of growth factors, such as transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta), which stimulate the production of collagen and other extracellular matrix components. This abnormal healing response results in the excessive growth of scar tissue beyond the original wound margin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The extent does not cross the wound margins: This statement is not true. Keloid scars are characterized by an excessive growth of fibrous tissue beyond the original wound margin. They tend to be larger, more raised, and thicker than the original wound.

 

Option B. Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence: This statement is also not entirely true. While surgical removal of keloid scars can be effective, the risk of recurrence is high, and the scar may actually grow larger than the original one.

 

Option C. Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity: This statement is not true. Keloid scars are characterized by an overproduction of collagen, which leads to the thick and raised appearance of the scar. There may also be increased vascularity within the scar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloid scars are caused by an overproduction of growth factors like TGF-β, leading to excessive collagen formation and scar tissue that extends beyond the wound margins.

choices.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21
It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about non-invasive prenatal testing? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21

 

Explanation:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening tool, not a diagnostic tool. It uses cell-free fetal DNA circulating in the maternal serum to screen for certain genetic conditions, including trisomies 13, 18, and 21.

 

NIPT is not used for diagnosis but for screening. It has high sensitivity (about 99%) for detecting trisomies 21, 18, and 13, but positive results must be confirmed with diagnostic tests such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum: Correct. NIPT uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum to assess the risk of certain genetic conditions in the fetus.

 

Option C. It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation: Correct. NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation, when there is enough fetal DNA in the maternal blood for accurate analysis.

 

Option D. It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment: Correct. NIPT is often done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment, which helps determine gestational age and detect multiple pregnancies or major anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening test for aneuploidy using cell-free fetal DNA in maternal serum, typically performed after 10 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page 890, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Nipah virus

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category A agent? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthrax

 

Anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Category A agents are those deemed highest risk for use in bioterrorism due to their ease of dissemination or transmission and their high potential for significant public health impact, resulting in high mortality rates and the potential for major public health impact.

 

  • Characteristics of Anthrax:
    • Transmission: Can occur through cutaneous, inhalational, or gastrointestinal exposure to spore-forming bacteria.
    • Impact: Especially deadly in its inhalational form, anthrax can cause severe respiratory issues, shock, and often death if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah virus: It is not classified as a category A agent. It is a zoonotic virus that can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis, primarily in Southeast Asia.

 

Option C. Coxiella: The bacterium that causes Q fever, is not classified as a category A agent. Q fever is typically acquired from infected animals or their products.

 

Option D. Brucella: It causes brucellosis, zoonotic infection primarily transmitted through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

 

Other category A agents are:

 

  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (Variola virus)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) - Francisella tularensis bacteria cause tularemia, also known as rabbit fever.

questions.text: The farmer presents with a cauliflower-like mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury, as depicted in the image. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of copper penny bodies. Based on this information, what is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chromoblastomycosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is chromoblastomycosis.

 

Chromoblastomycosis:

 

  • Causative Organism:  Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora species.
  • Clinical features: The initial presentation consists of warty papules that gradually enlarge, forming a hypertrophic plaque resembling cauliflower. Over the course of months to years, these lesions progress to large, hyperkeratotic masses with a surface often speckled with black dots.

 

 

Histopathology: Foreign body granuloma & Sclerotic / Medlar / Copper penny /Muriform bodies.

 

Treatment: Itraconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blastomycosis:

  • Caused by the fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis.
  • It primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other parts of the body, including the skin.
  • Skin manifestations can be ulcerative or verrucous but the presence of "copper penny bodies" is not a characteristic feature of this infection.
  • Thus, the microscopic finding does not match this option.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis/Rose Gardeners disease.

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear noduloulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Sporotrichoid lesions also seen in

 

  • FISH TANK/SWIMMING POOL GRANULOMA
  • LUPUS VULGARIS.

 

The given images show the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

Histopathology:  Asteroid bodies are seen.


Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Option D. Phaeohyphomycosis:

  • Represents a group of infections caused by various dematiaceous fungi.
  • Lesions can vary in appearance from nodules to cysts or abscesses.
  • Unlike chromoblastomycosis, phaeohyphomycosis does not characteristically have sclerotic or "copper penny" bodies under the microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its clinical presentation of verrucous skin lesions and the histopathological finding of sclerotic or copper penny bodies, indicative of infection with dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: Calcitonin levels are increased in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperparathyroidism

 

Calcitonin, a hormone secreted by the thyroid gland, is involved in the regulation of calcium levels in the body. In conditions where there is an increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, such as in hyperparathyroidism, there is a corresponding increase in blood calcium levels. The body responds to this hypercalcemia by increasing the secretion of calcitonin to help lower the calcium levels back to normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: While hyperthyroidism involves the thyroid gland, it does not typically result in increased calcitonin levels. Hyperthyroidism mainly increases thyroid hormones like thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), not calcitonin.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition is characterized by decreased PTH levels, leading to hypocalcemia (low calcium levels), not hypercalcemia that would stimulate calcitonin production.

 

Option D. Cushing's syndrome: Cushing's syndrome involves an excess of cortisol, a steroid hormone, and does not directly affect calcitonin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased calcitonin levels are typically seen in response to hypercalcemia, as seen in hyperparathyroidism. This is a compensatory mechanism to help maintain calcium homeostasis.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with features of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

 

  • In the given scenario of dilated pancreatic duct with stones, a drainage procedure in the form of longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy (Peusthow) is preferred.
  • CHRONIC PANCREATITIS - Irreversible damage to architecture of pancreas.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple’s procedure): This procedure involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and bile duct. It is typically reserved for malignancies or specific inflammatory conditions localized to the head of the pancreas. It is not the primary choice for diffuse chronic pancreatitis with a dilated duct.

 

Option C. ERCP and sphincterotomy: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with sphincterotomy can aid in the removal of pancreatic calculi but is not considered a long-term solution for chronic pancreatitis with a significantly dilated duct.

 

Option D. Coring of the pancreas head: Coring of the pancreatic head may be considered if inflammation is limited to the head of the pancreas alone, but it is not suitable for the diffuse dilation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with chronic pancreatitis and a significantly dilated pancreatic duct (greater than 6 mm), the preferred surgical treatment is longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (Peustow procedure).
  • This procedure helps to relieve ductal hypertension and improve drainage, alleviating pain and other symptoms associated with chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in the perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, yellow needle-shaped crystals are seen under the microscope. What is the test done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio’s Test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Option D. Acid phosphatase test: It’s a non-cellular Semen Markers i.e. markers are specific and unique to seminal plasma but independent of spermatozoa.

 

Finding a significantly elevated acid phosphatase level is consistent with the presence of semen. Undiluted semen has an acid phosphatase level of 340–360 Bodansky units/ml. A value of > 100 Bodansky units with/without motile sperms indicate that ejaculation occurred within 12 h of examination. Level decreases with time after intercourse, and there is little chance of identifying it after 48 h.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Non-cellular Semen Markers: Acid phosphatase test (quantitative), Prostate specific antigen or PSA (p30)

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry mouth, dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, and delirium. What could be the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dhatura


Dhatura poisoning is associated with anticholinergic toxidrome, which presents with features such as dry mouth, dilated pupils, dry skin, slurred speech, and delirium. Anticholinergic substances like Dhatura inhibit the action of acetylcholine, leading to reduced secretions, dilated pupils, and central nervous system effects like confusion and delirium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid and falls under the category of CNS depressants. Opioids typically cause pupil constriction (miosis), not dilation, and do not produce dry skin or dry mouth, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Alcohol: Alcohol, especially in the early stages, may cause pupil dilation but usually presents with wet skin and slurred speech due to CNS depression, not dry features. Dry skin and mouth are not characteristic of alcohol intoxication, making this option incorrect.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Cocaine is a sympathomimetic agent, which can cause pupil dilation but does not cause dry mouth or dry skin. Cocaine typically increases body secretions rather than reducing them, so this does not fit the anticholinergic profile described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:


Dhatura poisoning exhibits an anticholinergic toxidrome characterized by dry mouth, dry skin, dilated pupils, and altered mental status, distinguishing it from other toxidromes.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with chronic low back pain and early morning stiffness since last 2 years, which is also associated with bilateral heel pain. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints; B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TB spine. In pott’s spine, the commonest & usually the 1st symptom is back pain, which is usually minimal. Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for Anterior elements is more significant as disease is anteriorly involving the vertebral body (paradiscal). Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When bending forward, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine are in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier). The Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm. There is reduction of intervertebral disk space and osteoporosis of two adjacent vertebrae, sometimes with fuzziness of the endplates. Paraspinal abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.

 

 

Option C. Mechanical back pain. Mechanical back strain is a subtype of back pain where the etiology is the spine, intervertebral discs, or the surrounding soft tissues. Lower back is usually affected the most. More than 80% of people will suffer from low back pain during their lifetime. There is a higher prevalence among women and people ages 40-80 years. Acute mechanical back strains may be triggered by physical or non-physical activity, with lifting being the most commonly recalled event. The patient complaints of axial lumbosacral pain and/or radicular pain into the lower extremity. Low back pain does not necessarily correlate with imaging findings. Plain radiograph is suitable to assess bony abnormalities or fractures.

 

Option D. Prolapsed intervertebral disc. The commonest site of disc prolapse is lumbar spine. In more than 95% of cases lumbar disc herniation are localized at L4-L5 (50% cases) and L5-S1 (45% cases). The next commonest site of intervertebral disc prolapse is lower cervical spine (C5-C6). Lumbar disc is dehydrated hence more prone. Small herniation of nucleus pulposus produce Schmorl’s nodules. Degenerated disc is extruded posteriorly in three patterns: Central, Paracentral (annulus bulges to one side of posterior longitudinal ligament – most common type and produced unilateral radicular symptoms), and Far lateral disc herniation (bulge is within or just lateral to neural foramina).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of chronic low back pain, early morning stiffness, and bilateral heel pain are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis which involves the enthesis of the body.

questions.text: A female present with pain and swelling over multiple peripheral small joints and deformity as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

  • The image shows swan neck deformity seen in RA.
  • Characteristic Deformities of Hand and Foot In RA:

 

 

 

 

Finger deformities in RA

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthropathy. Five patterns of joint involvement are seen: Arthritis of DIP joint, Asymmetrical oligoarthritis, Symmetrical polyarthritis, Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint), and Arthritis mutilans. Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis. Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common Shortening of digitis (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis. Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA). Almost any peripheral joint can be involved. Radiological Features includes classical pencil cup deformity of DIP joints.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand. Sparing of wrist and MCP is a feature of Osteoarthritis.

 

 

Option D. Scleroderma. Scleroderma is a severe CTD characterized by vascular, immune and fibrotic changes in the skin and internal organs. While tethering of the skin is the clinical hallmark of SSc, many patients develop musculoskeletal symptoms also. Manifestations may include rheumatic complaints ranging from arthralgias to frank arthritis, contractures and tendon friction rubs. Articular involvement contributes to disability and impaired quality of life. All joints may be affected, although the fingers (in particular the MCP and PIP joints), wrists and ankles predominate. As the disease progresses, there is tethering and contracture of the joints with impairment of movement and function.

 

 

Calcinosis and contracture of joints

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows swan neck deformity, which is characteristic of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

 

Explanation

 

Decerebrate rigidity is the rigid extension of all the limbs due to decerebration. This type of rigidity is well pronounced in the extensor muscles. The term decerebrate rigidity was coined by Sherrington in 1897.

 

Reason for decerebrate rigidity:

 

  • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent.
  • From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity.
  • Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by

 

  1. γ motor neuron discharge rate increased.
  2. Motor neuron pool excitability increased.
  3. Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock.
  4. Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron: Correct as part of the characterization of decerebrate rigidity. The increased discharge rate of the γ efferent neurons enhances the muscle spindle responses, contributing to increased muscle tone.

 

Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool: Correct, this increased excitability leads to the hyperactivity of motor neurons, particularly those controlling the extensor muscles.

 

Option D. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock: Correct, unlike spinal shock, which involves a temporary reduction or loss of reflex activity below the level of a spinal cord injury, decerebration does not produce a similar transient reduction in reflexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by an increase in extensor muscle tone due to enhanced activity of the γ motor neurons and increased excitability of the motor neuron pool, without inducing effects similar to spinal shock. Rigidity does not occur in all muscles of the body but is more pronounced in antigravity extensor muscles.

questions.text: Identify the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroid


The image shows a well-circumscribed, whitish lesion within the uterine cavity, which is characteristic of a submucosal fibroid. Fibroids, also known as leiomyomas, are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus. They can present as distinct, well-defined lesions that are separate from the normal myometrial tissue, often appearing white or light in color compared to the surrounding pink myometrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Adenomyosis:  is incorrect because adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, leading to a uniformly enlarged and diffusely thickened uterus without distinct, well-defined lesions.

 

Option C. Endometrial polyp:  is incorrect as polyps are usually small, soft, and protruding growths that arise from the endometrial lining. They do not appear as a well-defined, firm, and large mass like the fibroid shown.

 

Option D. Endometrial cancer: is incorrect because endometrial cancer typically presents as irregular, vascular, and possibly friable growths within the uterine cavity, not as a smooth, well-defined mass.

 

Educational Objective:


Fibroids are well-defined, circumscribed lesions within the uterine cavity that are distinct in color and structure compared to surrounding myometrial tissue, distinguishing them from other uterine conditions like adenomyosis, polyps, and cancer.

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliverdin 

 

Meconium is a dark and sticky substance that is normally present in a newborn's intestine at birth and is excreted in the feces after birth. It is first detected in the ileum at around 70-85 days of fetal life and fills the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of meconium is due to bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract, mainly biliverdin, which is formed from the oxidation of bilirubin.

 

  • Biliverdin is responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in newborns. Biliverdin production starts later in gestation or closer to delivery, perhaps due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system.
  • Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.
  • Meconium itself is the first stool of the baby, which contains biliverdin, giving it the greenish-black color.
  • Gut flora: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Option C. Meconium: Meconium is the substance itself, not the cause of its greenish-black color. The color is due to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Gut flora of neonate: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in a newborn is due to biliverdin, a bile pigment.

questions.text: Which vitamin, when infused in supraphysiological doses, causes macular edema and macular cysts? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B3

 

Supraphysiological doses of Vitamin B3, also known as Niacin, have been known to cause adverse effects, including macular edema and macular cysts. This side effect is relatively rare but has been documented in some cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to various eye problems, but it is not associated with macular edema and macular cysts caused by supraphysiological doses.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D is essential for various bodily functions, including bone health, but it is not known to cause macular edema or macular cysts.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant that helps protect cells from damage, but it is not associated with macular edema or macular cysts caused by supraphysiological doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicotinic acid when given orally or parenterally produces a transient vasodilatation of the cutaneous vessels and histamine release. The reaction is accompanied by itching, burning and tingling. Intake of nicotinic acid in excess of 50 mg/day may lead to liver damage (Raised AST and ALT levels, Fulminant hepatitis)

 

Niacin causes a reversible toxic cystoid maculopathy that occurs in approximately 0.67% of patients taking high doses of the drug.

 

Other symptoms –

 

  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Glucose intolerance (therefore weekly glucose monitoring done if given in diabetics)
  • Hyperuricemia

questions.text: A vagabond roaming in the forest eats some unknown fruits. After sometime he starts having symptoms of irritability, restlessness, dry hot skin, and was unable to pass urine and stools. Identify the poison and its appropriate antidote: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

Diagnostic features of Datura poisoning in the question

 

  • Datura has mainly neurotoxic (Irritability, restlessness) and anticholinergic features (Dry hot skin, unable to urinate and pass stool)
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice for Datura

 

Datura poisoning:

 

  • Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.
  • Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.
  • Features of Datura poisoning (D's of Datura): Dry hot skin, Dilatation of pupils, Diplopia, Dry mouth, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Drunken gait, Delirium, Drowsiness, Death.
  • Datura causes constipation, not diarrhoea

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning:

 

  • Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug.
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice
  • Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning, not for anticholinergic toxicity caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Digoxin: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside and not an antidote. The treatment for yellow oleander poisoning includes atropine and antiarrhythmics, not digoxin.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Physostigmine is not the antidote for yellow oleander poisoning, which primarily affects the heart rather than causing anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • There are two oleander plants: Nerium odorum and Cerbera Thevetia
  • Both are cardiac poisons
  • Both have digoxin like toxicity:
    • Heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse).
    • Similar to digitalis.
    •  Muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning.
  • Treatment of Both Oleander poisoning:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies for severe arrhythmias

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning is characterized by neurotoxic and anticholinergic symptoms, and the appropriate antidote is Physostigmine, which can cross the blood-brain barrier and reverse CNS toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+

 

ER+ is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients as it is seen with luminal A and B subtypes of the breast cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High Ki67+: High Ki67+ indicates a high proliferative index, which is associated with more aggressive tumors and a poorer prognosis.

 

Option C. BRCA1+: BRCA1 mutation is associated with an increased risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers, and these cancers tend to be more aggressive.

 

Option D. P53+: P53 mutations are associated with a variety of cancers and typically indicate a poorer prognosis due to the loss of normal p53 tumor suppressor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER-positive status in breast cancer is a good prognostic factor because it indicates a slower-growing tumor that is likely to respond well to hormone therapy.

 

Why ER⁺ is a Good Prognostic Factor:

 

  1. Slower tumor growth:
    • ER⁺ tumors tend to grow more slowly than ER⁻ tumors.
  2. Better treatment response:
    • ER⁺ cancers respond well to hormonal therapies such as:
    • Tamoxifen
    • Aromatase inhibitors
  3. Lower recurrence risk:
    • Hormone receptor–positive cancers have a lower risk of early recurrence.
  4. Overall survival:
    • Patients with ER⁺ tumors generally have better overall survival.

questions.text: Which adult structure is derived from the embryological remnant marked as ‘A’ in the diagram? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median umbilical ligament
