Marked structure A is the allantois, which forms the urachus, which in turn gives rise to the median umbilical ligament.

 

The median umbilical ligament represents the remnant of the urachus (also known as the median umbilical fold). The urachus is a tubular structure that connects the fetal bladder to the umbilical cord and allows for the drainage of urine produced by the fetal kidneys into the amniotic fluid.

 

After birth, the urachus becomes non-functional and fibroses to form the median umbilical ligament. It extends from the apex of the bladder to the umbilicus within the median umbilical fold.

 

The given image shows an embryo at the end of the third week.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial umbilical ligament: These are the remnants of the occluded parts of the umbilical arteries. In fetal life, the umbilical arteries arise from the internal iliac arteries and pass to the umbilical cord, carrying deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

 

  • In the adult, they persist as the medial umbilical ligaments, which are paired fibrous bands on the inner surface of the anterior abdominal wall, running from the bladder to the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum arises from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct (or omphalomesenteric duct), which connects the yolk sac to the midgut lumen during embryonic development. It usually disappears by the 7th week of embryonic life.

 

  • If a portion of the vitelline duct remains, it can manifest as a Meckel's diverticulum. It's found in approximately 2% of the population and is often described by the "rule of 2s" - 2 inches long, 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, 2% of the population, and can present with two types of epithelia (gastric and pancreatic).

 

Option D. Ligamentum teres (Round ligament of the liver):

 

  • The ligamentum teres represents the obliterated remnant of the left umbilical vein. During fetal development, the left umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta directly to the fetal heart, bypassing the liver through the ductus venosus.
  • After birth, the need for this shunt ceases, and the ductus venosus along with the left umbilical vein close up. The ligamentum teres runs in the free margin of the falciform ligament, connecting the umbilicus to the anterior aspect of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

 

Explanation:

 

The provided images depict the components and functioning of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, a key multienzyme complex in the metabolic pathway that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, an essential step linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. This complex requires vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoic acid as cofactors.

 

Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as Pyruvate Decarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in this context, and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is the E3 component of the complex.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase: Incorrect because Pyruvate carboxylase is involved in a different metabolic pathway (gluconeogenesis), not in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as the second enzyme is E3 in this complex, not E2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 162

choices.text: Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months
Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years

questions.text: While discharging a patient who underwent a vesicovaginal fistula repair, which of the following would you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year

 

Explanation:

 

  • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of urinary fistula that commonly arises due to obstetric trauma.
  • Small fistulas can heal spontaneously; however, most established fistulas require surgical repair.
  • The surgical repair is usually performed vaginally after approximately 3 months to allow inflammation to subside.
  • Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended to facilitate healing.
  • Following VVF repair, it is recommended that the patient abstain from sexual activity for 3 months to allow the surgical site to heal properly and avoid complications.
  • Additionally, pregnancy should be avoided for a year to ensure the integrity and strength of the repair before subjecting the area to the stresses of pregnancy and childbirth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months: This duration of abstinence is too short for the proper healing of the surgical site. Additionally, avoiding pregnancy for only 6 months might not provide sufficient time for the repair to gain adequate strength.

 

Option C. Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year: While the recommendation to avoid pregnancy for a year is appropriate, 6 weeks of sexual abstinence may still be insufficient for optimal healing of the fistula repair.

 

Option D. Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years: This recommendation is excessively long. While prolonged abstinence can prevent complications, a 6-month period is more than what is typically necessary. Similarly, avoiding pregnancy for 6 years is overly cautious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following vesicovaginal fistula repair, patients should be advised to abstain from sexual activity for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year to ensure proper healing and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Ref: Page 439, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABCC2

 

Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is ABCC2 (codes for canalicular protein with ATP-binding cassette), it leads to the mutation of multiple drug-resistant protein 2 (MRP2) receptor. Hence, there is a defect in the transfer of conjugated bilirubin from the liver to bile in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A: This gene is associated with Menkes disease, a disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option B. ATP7B: This gene is associated with Wilson's disease, another disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option D. SERPINA1: This gene is associated with Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, a condition that can lead to liver and lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is in the ABCC2 gene, which encodes for a canalicular protein involved in the excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

 

In the given clinical scenario, the boy exhibits typical signs and symptoms of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). HSP is a type of small vessel vasculitis that commonly affects children. It is characterized by the presence of a purpuric rash, as well as arthritis and abdominal pain. Additionally, approximately 50% of patients with HSP develop renal complications that can range from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

 

In patients with HSP, the onset of nephritis typically follows the development of the rash. The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis is believed to be associated with the deposition of polymeric immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.

 

  • Here are some common types of vasculitis that can affect children.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE typically presents with a butterfly malar rash over the face, especially involving the nasolabial folds. It also includes systemic symptoms like fever, joint pain, and renal involvement, but the presentation and rash pattern differ from HSP.

 

Option C. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP): ITP presents with petechiae all over the body due to thrombocytopenia, and the patient typically has a low platelet count. Peripheral smear usually shows an increase in megakaryocytes.

 

Option D. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): PAN is a medium vessel vasculitis that presents with fever, abdominal pain, skin changes like livedo reticularis, muscle and joint pain, and neuropathy. It does not typically present with the purpuric rash and renal involvement seen in HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is characterized by a purpuric rash, arthritis, abdominal pain, and renal complications such as hematuria and proteinuria, typically following the rash development.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented with chest pain. In an angiogram, her left circumflex artery was found to be stenosed, and a stent was inserted. Her current medications include ASA 75mg OD, atenolol 50mg BID, lovastatin, and lisinopril. What should be done in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Add P2Y12 receptor inhibitor

 

After stent placement, it is crucial to prevent stent thrombosis, which can be life-threatening. Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) is the standard of care in this scenario. DAPT includes aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor). These medications work synergistically to inhibit platelet aggregation and prevent thrombus formation within the stent.

 

The patient is already on aspirin 75 mg daily, so the addition of a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor is necessary to complete the DAPT regimen. This combination has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of stent thrombosis and other cardiovascular events after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement.

 

Guidelines on the duration of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) –

 

  • Drug-Eluting Stents (DES): A minimum of 6 months of DAPT is recommended. This therapy usually involves the use of aspirin combined with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) to prevent clot formation around the new stent.
  • Bare Metal Stents (BMS): At least 1 month of DAPT is required. Although the duration is shorter than that for DES, it's crucial for preventing early stent thrombosis.
  • Stents Inserted for Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): If a stent is inserted as part of treatment for ACS, the recommended minimum duration of DAPT extends to 12 months. This extended period helps manage the higher risk of thrombosis and other complications associated with ACS.
  • Current Patient Situation: Ongoing Medication: The patient is already on aspirin. A P2Y12 receptor inhibitor needs to be added to the regimen to complete the DAPT, ensuring optimal protection against clotting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase Aspirin dose: Increasing the aspirin dose does not provide additional benefit in preventing stent thrombosis and is not recommended as part of DAPT. The current dose of 75 mg is adequate when combined with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor.

 

Option B. Increase atenolol dose: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is used for managing hypertension and angina but does not prevent stent thrombosis. Increasing its dose does not address the immediate need for antiplatelet therapy post-stent placement.

 

Option C. Add a Long-Acting Nitrate: Long-acting nitrates can help manage angina symptoms but do not prevent stent thrombosis. They are not part of the recommended therapy to prevent thrombotic complications after stent placement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After stent placement, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor) is essential to prevent stent thrombosis and ensure optimal patient outcomes.

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all of the following except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fingerprint pattern

 

Monozygotic twins (Identical twins) are conceived when a single egg fertilized by a single sperm splits into two after fertilization. Such twins have 100% of their genes in common. Both of them invariably have the same blood type and are of the same sex.

 

 Dizygotic twins (Faternal twins) are conceived when two eggs are fertilized by two different sperms. They share 50% of their genes, just like any other siblings. Their blood types and sex can be either same or different.

 

So, all the inheritable characteristics will be exactly same in identical twins (e.g. Blood group, DNA fingerprinting, Iris Color).

 

But Fingerprints are not inheritable hence different even in identical twins. No finger-prints of 2 individuals are similar. It is 100% accurate method of identification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood Group: Identical twins invariably have the same blood type.

 

Option B. DNA Fingerprinting: Identical twins have identical DNA profiles because they share the same genetic material.

 

Option D. Iris Color: Iris color, being a genetic trait, will be the same in identical twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While identical twins share the same blood group, DNA fingerprinting, and iris color due to their identical genetic makeup, their fingerprint patterns are unique to each individual due to non-inheritable factors.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a rapidly growing, painless mass in her right breast that she first noticed about 3 months ago. On physical examination, the mass is well-circumscribed, lobulated, and larger than 5 cm in diameter. A history of a similar lesion occurred 2 years back also. A core needle biopsy is performed, and the histological examination reveals the image as shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phyllodes tumor

 

Phyllodes tumor is a rare breast tumor that typically presents in middle-aged women (fourth to fifth decade). It is characterized by rapid growth, a lobulated appearance, and often exceeds 5 cm in diameter.

 

Phyllodes tumors can be distinguished from fibroadenomas by their stromal overgrowth and the presence of characteristic leaf-like projections seen in histological examinations. The image shows a stromal tumor with these classical leaf-like projections, confirming the diagnosis of Phyllodes tumor.

 

Phyllodes tumors can recur and have a low risk of becoming malignant, setting them apart from benign fibroadenomas and malignant carcinomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma: This is the most common type of breast cancer, characterized by a solid mass with irregular borders. It typically presents with more aggressive features, such as lymphovascular invasion, which are absent in this case. The histology does not show the leaf-like stromal projections seen in Phyllodes tumors.

 

Option C. Fibroadenoma: A common benign breast tumor seen mostly in younger women, characterized by a well-circumscribed, mobile mass. Histologically, it shows a mix of glandular and stromal elements but lacks the prominent stromal overgrowth and leaf-like projections seen in Phyllodes tumors.

 

Option D. Ductal papilloma: This benign tumor involves the breast ducts and often presents with nipple discharge rather than a large, rapidly growing mass. The histological appearance is distinct from that of Phyllodes tumors, lacking the stromal and leaf-like characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phyllodes tumors are rapidly growing, lobulated breast masses with characteristic leaf-like stromal projections on histology, commonly seen in middle-aged women, and may recur.

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the following EEG finding? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM sleep

 

EEG recording is showing "Sawtooth waves" which are characteristic of REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. REM sleep is also associated with rapid eye movements, muscle atonia (paralysis), and dreaming.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Transition between wakefulness and sleep, contains theta waves.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Deep sleep or slow-wave sleep, characterized by delta waves.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep follows NREM sleep. EEG in REM sleep shows sawtooth waves and increased activity similar to awake state (beta activity) along with return of alpha activity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 534.

questions.text: Identify the procedure based on the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nissen Fundoplication

 

The correct procedure is Nissen Fundoplication. Nissen fundoplication involves a complete 360-degree wrap of the gastric fundus around the lower esophagus to reinforce the lower esophageal sphincter, which helps prevent gastroesophageal reflux. The image shows a complete wrap around the gastroesophageal junction, characteristic of the Nissen procedure. This procedure is commonly performed to treat severe gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or hiatal hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toupet Fundoplication: Toupet fundoplication is a partial (270-degree) posterior wrap of the gastric fundus around the esophagus. This procedure is less constrictive than Nissen fundoplication and is often used in patients with esophageal motility disorders. The image does not depict the 270-degree posterior wrap seen in Toupet fundoplication.

 

Option C. Dor Fundoplication: Dor fundoplication is a partial (180-200 degree) anterior wrap of the gastric fundus around the esophagus. It is often used as a complementary procedure to surgeries such as Heller myotomy for achalasia. The wrap shown in the image is complete and not partial, ruling out Dor fundoplication.

 

Option D. Gastrectomy: Gastrectomy refers to the surgical removal of part or all of the stomach, often performed for conditions like gastric cancer or severe peptic ulcer disease. The image does not show any removal of stomach tissue, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Nissen Fundoplication is a surgical procedure involving a complete 360-degree wrap of the gastric fundus around the lower esophagus to prevent gastroesophageal reflux. It is distinct from other partial fundoplication techniques such as Toupet and Dor, which involve less than a full wrap.

questions.text: According to wound ballistics, A gunshot wound showing burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound, can be classified as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close shot entry wound

 

Burning (heat of the gases), blackening (deposition of soot) and tattooing (unburned powder particles embedding into the skin) are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds do not show burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are usually larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They show a clean entry hole.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Exit wounds from distant shots also do not show these features and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

choices.text: Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body
It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly
The syndrome is a result of gun injuries

questions.text: Identify the true statement from the following about battered baby syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body

 

Battered child syndrome is defined as the collection of injuries sustained by a child as a result of repeated mistreatment or beating. If a child's injuries indicate intentional trauma or appear to be more severe than could reasonably be expected to result from an accident, battered child syndrome should be suspected.

 

Skin lesions and bruises of different ages (from young to old) are a classical feature of a child with battered baby syndrome.

 

Skeletal survey helps in identifying bone injuries in Battered Baby syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly: False: While children do fall frequently, the pattern and severity of injuries in battered child syndrome are inconsistent with typical childhood falls and accidents.

 

Option C. Stab wounds are obvious: False: Stab wounds are not a common feature of battered child syndrome. The syndrome primarily involves bruises, fractures, and other signs of physical abuse.

 

Option D. The syndrome is a result of gun injuries: False: Battered child syndrome is not characterized by gun injuries. It involves repeated physical abuse, leading to various types of trauma, particularly bruises and fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battered child syndrome is characterized by the presence of skin lesions and bruises of different ages, indicating repeated and ongoing physical abuse.
